newsitem.title: GERMANY: EMI calls for urgent labour market reforms.
newsitem.headline: EMI calls for urgent labour market reforms.

text.p: The European Monetary Institute (EMI) said on Tuesday that urgent action was needed to revive European Union labour markets and halt the acceleration in unemployment rates.

"Unemployment trends are...extremely worrisome; in my view the recent record of the Union in terms of job creation is dismal," EMI President Alexandre Lamfalussy said in a foreword to the EMI's annual report.
The EMI said that efforts to solve structural labour market problems in the EU had been generally inadequate.
"Further progress remains an urgent necessity in order to revive labour markets and to reverse the pattern of low unemployment growth and increasing unemployment rates," the report said.

Institutional rigidities on social security, working hours, contract terms and collective bargaining practices accounted for the weak performance of labor markets and it would be "a major challenge for most member states to challenge them in a decisive and sustained manner," the EMI said.
Lamfalussy noted that employment in the European Union region had barely risen since the cyclical trough of 1993 and that projections envisaged little improvement.

"This points to the crucial need for continued labour cost moderation and enhanced labour market reforms, for it is evident that the recovery of output growth alone will be insufficient to remedy deep-seated structural patterns of unemployment," Lamfalussy said.
